Treatment with the JAK inhibitor, tofacitinib, reversed the elevated ACE2 expression and reduced viral entry, providing insights into potential therapeutic interventions for individuals carrying this SNP.
title: Identification of a Novel Susceptibility Marker for SARS-CoV-2 Infection in Human Subjects and Risk Mitigation with a Clinically Approved JAK Inhibitor in Human/Mouse Cells

finding: This SNP replicated previous findings related to neuroticism, indicating its relevance in psychiatric phenotypes broadly defined under mood disturbances.
title: Multivariate GWAS of psychiatric disorders and their cardinal symptoms reveal two dimensions of cross-cutting genetic liabilities

finding: The study reported that SNP rs17782313 was associated with obesity and increased risk for type 2 diabetes (T2D) specifically in women. Earlier findings indicated that this SNP linked to obesity risk showed a greater impact on body mass index (BMI) increase in females compared to males, and was further supported by evidence showing that women with the gain-of-function mutation V103I experienced a more notable reduction in BMI than their male counterparts.
title: Mouse models for V103I and I251L gain of function variants of the human MC4R display reduced adiposity and are not protected from a hypercaloric diet

finding: The SNP rs11081208 was associated with the bioactive properties of polyphenols from Andean potatoes, specifically demonstrating a role in programmed cell death through a caspase-independent pathway. These findings indicated that the SNP may correlate with therapeutic effects of Andean potato compounds in neuroblastoma cells, suggesting its relevance in cancer treatment.
title: Red-purple Andean potato polyphenols have an anti-neuroblastoma effect in vitro via apoptosis through mitochondria

finding: The SNP rs9947450, located within the MC4R gene, had a notable positive effect on energy portion size in short individuals (beta=2.74, p-value=8.99×10−5). This indicated its relevance in dietary behavior among short people.
title: Genome-wide analyses point to differences in genetic architecture of BMI between tall and short people

finding: The SNP rs10502437 showed colocalisation with eQTLs in both low-grade and high-grade cartilage, indicating its significance in the molecular landscape of osteoarthritis as derived from the GWAS analysis.
title: Decoding the genomic basis of osteoarthritis

finding: The SNP rs17828933 was associated with higher expression of the CD6Δd3 isoform, which lacks the d3 region necessary for binding to the primary ligand CD166. This alteration in isoform expression correlated with increased susceptibility to multiple sclerosis (MS). The finding indicated that the presence of this SNP impacted immune response by favoring the expression of a form of CD6 that may diminish its immunoregulatory functions.
title: The dual character of the inhibitory functions of CD6

finding: This SNP was noted for causing a 40-fold decline in SP1 transcription factor binding affinity. SP1 has been implicated in behavioral abnormalities associated with SCZ. Moreover, rs8091497 was associated with the potassium transport gene KCNG2, one of the genes prioritized in relation to SCH.
title: Unveiling causal regulatory mechanisms through cell-state parallax

finding: The SNP rs8090726 was associated with the study on validating plant phenology data using citizen science. It was part of research indicating that citizen science efforts, like the iNaturalist platform, can significantly enhance the amount of phenology observations and provide necessary spatial coverage for estimating flowering onset.
title: Opportunistically collected photographs can be used to estimate large-scale phenological trends

finding: The SNP rs17089887 was identified in a study that demonstrated a genetic association with Fuchs' endothelial corneal dystrophy (FECD) in an Indian population. This finding suggested that polymorphisms in the TCF4 gene, specifically intronic variations, contributed to the susceptibility of individuals to early-onset FECD, linking genetic mutations with the phenotype characterized by progressive vision impairment due to the loss of corneal endothelial cells.
title: Start codon disruption with CRISPR/Cas9 prevents murine Fuchs’ endothelial corneal dystrophy

finding: The SNP rs11081213 was associated with variations in immune checkpoint expression in relation to epithelial-mesenchymal transition (EMT) status in tumors. The study suggested that this genetic variation could influence the effectiveness of immune response in cancer treatments by modifying checkpoint markers, highlighting its potential role in mediating immune evasion.
title: Analysis of immune subtypes across the epithelial-mesenchymal plasticity spectrum

finding: The SNP rs117771145 was associated with the down-regulation of TAS2R41 and also showed significant associations with the upregulation of EPHB6 and ADGRB3. This SNP was consistently linked to Alzheimer's disease across four GWAS studies, suggesting its role in influencing taste perception pathways that may impact neurodegeneration.
title: Genomic Study of Taste Perception Genes in African Americans Reveals SNPs Linked to Alzheimer’s Disease

finding: This SNP was observed to be most associated with HDL in the Framingham Heart Study, confirming its role in HDL dynamics as validated by the study's findings.
title: Multi-scale Inference of Genetic Trait Architecture using Biologically Annotated Neural Networks

finding: In contrast to rs7240405, which was more relevant in the Framingham cohort, rs7244811 was identified in the UK Biobank as associated with HDL, demonstrating variability in SNP significance between the two studies.
title: Multi-scale Inference of Genetic Trait Architecture using Biologically Annotated Neural Networks

finding: This SNP was found to be significant for HDL in the UK Biobank analysis, adding to the understanding of the intergenic region's involvement in cholesterol regulation.
title: Multi-scale Inference of Genetic Trait Architecture using Biologically Annotated Neural Networks

finding: The SNP rs11081162 was identified as having a significant role in the pathogenesis of epithelial cancers through the WNT co-receptor LRP6. This association suggested that this SNP could be influential in the development and therapy of such cancers, establishing it as a relevant biomarker in oncology.
title: DPHL v2: An updated and comprehensive DIA pan-human assay library for quantifying more than 14,000 proteins

finding: The maximum logarithm of the odds (LOD) score of 4.93 was obtained for marker rs928980, indicating a strong association with the phenotype of late-onset, progressive, non-syndromic hearing loss in the studied family.
title: THOC1 deficiency leads to late-onset nonsyndromic hearing loss through p53-mediated hair cell apoptosis

finding: Linkage analysis identified a critical interval on Chromosome 18p11.3 between markers rs4797697 and rs11080868, suggesting a potential genetic region involved in late-onset hearing loss.
title: THOC1 deficiency leads to late-onset nonsyndromic hearing loss through p53-mediated hair cell apoptosis

finding: Marker rs11080868 was part of the defined critical interval on Chromosome 18p11.3 linked to late-onset hearing loss, providing evidence for its role in the genetic basis of the condition.
title: THOC1 deficiency leads to late-onset nonsyndromic hearing loss through p53-mediated hair cell apoptosis

finding: In the study, rs1022177 was shown to have a maximum LOD score of 4.93, contributing to the evidence for genetic factors associated with late-onset hearing loss.
title: THOC1 deficiency leads to late-onset nonsyndromic hearing loss through p53-mediated hair cell apoptosis

finding: As part of the linkage analysis, rs12709528 was highlighted with a high LOD score of 4.93, indicating its significance in the genetic analysis of late-onset, non-syndromic hearing loss.
title: THOC1 deficiency leads to late-onset nonsyndromic hearing loss through p53-mediated hair cell apoptosis

finding: The SNP rs1559586 was also significant in the non-stratified GWAS for systemizing, with a p-value of 4.78×10−8. This SNP is located in a region of high genetic recombination and relates to genetic factors associated with autism.
title: Social and non-social autism symptom and trait domains are genetically dissociable

finding: The T allele at rs28630791 exerted a strong impact on the expression of the DSC1 gene in mid-pubertal girls. DSC1 encodes a protein that is essential for maintaining cell junctions, and its expression was significantly modulated in relation to the genetic variant during puberty.
title: Analysis of transcriptional changes associated with pubertal development

finding: The SNP rs8084351 located in the 18q21.2 region near the DCC gene showed the most significant pleiotropic associations, linked with all eight psychiatric disorders analyzed, including Major Depression (MD). DCC was found to play a crucial role in neurodevelopment.
title: Genome wide meta-analysis identifies genomic relationships, novel loci, and pleiotropic mechanisms across eight psychiatric disorders

finding: rs11663049, located within an E2F5 transcription factor binding site, disrupted the E2F5 motif. This disruption modified the regulatory relationship, significantly affecting the expression of the gene CEP192.
title: Comprehensive profiling of transcriptional regulation in cartilage reveals pathogenesis of osteoarthritis

finding: The SNP rs2272783 A>G in FECH was associated with erythropoietic protoporphyria and exhibited allele frequencies that were nearly three times higher in the Vietnamese (28.10%) and East Asian populations (32.57%) than in the world population (11.23%), indicating a higher prevalence of this condition in these regions.
title: Genetic profiling of 2,683 Vietnamese genomes from non-invasive prenatal testing data

finding: The rs11081207 SNP was associated with increased rates of tumour mass dormancy, reflecting a potential link with immune exhaustion and angiogenesis regulation. This finding was identified within a broader context of genomic factors influencing cancer dormancy, suggesting implications for better understanding cancer progression and patient survival.
title: Pan-cancer survey of tumour mass dormancy and underlying mutational processes

finding: The SNP rs8090080 was associated with Wnt signaling mechanisms as explored in the context of cell motility and invasion. The study provided insights into how Wnt signaling pathways are linked to both developmental processes and cancer, indicating that alterations in this SNP may affect cancer progression and the cellular behavior tied to Wnt-mediated asymmetric cell division (ACD). This finding emphasized the relevance of Wnt signaling in cell fate determination and its potential implications in cancer biology.
title: Wnt- and Glutamate-receptors orchestrate stem cell dynamics and asymmetric cell division

finding: The SNP rs11873030, which was associated with multiple sclerosis as established by the International Multiple Sclerosis Genetics Consortium in 2011, demonstrated a significant sQTL effect on the junction read unique to the MALT1-1 isoform. It was noted that the expression of this isoform decreased with the risk allele (C allele) for multiple sclerosis.
title: Immune Isoform Atlas: Landscape of alternative splicing in human immune cells

finding: The study indicated that rs11081121 was associated with the retention of chromogranin A (CHGA) in dense core granules (DCGs) of chromaffin cells, thus playing a critical role in catecholamine (like epinephrine) storage. The context emphasized that loss of Nod1 ligands, which this SNP may influence, led to impaired stress responses in the adrenal medulla by affecting catecholamine storage and secretion during stress responses in mice.
title: Intestinal microbiota modulates adrenomedullary response through Nod1 sensing in chromaffin cells

finding: The SNP rs11081162 was linked to the WNT co-receptor LRP6, which was associated with the pathogenesis and therapy of epithelial cancers, including lung adenocarcinoma (LUAD). This finding indicated that variations at this locus could influence cancer progression and therapeutic responses, making it relevant for understanding LUAD prognosis.
title: Reconstructing co-dependent cellular crosstalk in lung adenocarcinoma using REMI

finding: The maspin polymorphism P176S (rs2289519) was linked to promoting gastric cancer. This finding suggested that the presence of the Serine (S) at position 176 of maspin could be implicated in a pro-tumor role in gastric malignancies.
title: P176S polymorphism in Maspin rewires electrostatic interaction that alters Maspin functionality

finding: The V187L polymorphism (rs2289520) was associated with oral cancer, indicating that the variant at this position could contribute to the pathogenesis of oral malignancies.
title: P176S polymorphism in Maspin rewires electrostatic interaction that alters Maspin functionality

finding: The study reported that SNP rs11081050 was associated with a significant downregulation of signaling pathways linked to tumor growth, metastasis, and hypoxia in human triple-negative breast cancer when PD-L1 blockade was applied using Atezolizumab. This highlighted an important role for this SNP in influencing the efficacy of PD-L1 targeted therapies.
title: Therapeutic anti-PD-L1 antibody affects ESCRT-mediated functions in cells expressing oncogenic EGFR

finding: Found associated with risk of ER-positive disease (P<0.05).
title: Common breast cancer risk loci predispose to distinct tumor subtypes

finding: The SNP rs4987855 showed significant linkage to NHL risk, being in high LD with another NHL risk variant, establishing a connection to lymphocytic leukemia.
title: Cross-Cancer Evaluation of Polygenic Risk Scores for 17 Cancer Types in Two Large Cohorts

finding: There was an association identified between the lncRNA SNHG8 and rs7241781 specifically in a subset of B cells, suggesting a link between this SNP and gene expression variation relevant to immune response.
title: Expression QTLs in single-cell sequencing data

finding: The SNP rs11081145 was associated with B cell infiltration in colorectal cancer (CRC), particularly in KRAS-driven lung adenocarcinoma studies. This finding highlighted the potential role of B cells in the tumor microenvironment and their implications for developing targeted immunotherapy approaches in CRC.
title: Dissecting heterogeneity of tumor microenvironment in colorectal cancer using high-resolution single-cell atlas

finding: The SNP rs11081178 was associated with the modulation of the p21 pathway in cancer research. In the context of medulloblastoma, it indicated a significant role in altering the expression levels of p21, impacting cancer stem cell characteristics and suggesting potential therapeutic implications.
title: Modulation of Viability, Proliferation, and Stemness by Rosmarinic Acid in Medulloblastoma Cells: Involvement of HDACs and EGFR

finding: The SNP rs4800490, near NPC1, was also an outlier related to several candidate traits, notably influencing BMI. The analysis suggested that this SNP was part of the heterogeneity contributors in the schooling-BMI causal assessment.
title: MR-TRYX: A Mendelian randomization framework that exploits horizontal pleiotropy to infer novel causal pathways

finding: The variant rs2847297 at the PTPN2 locus was associated with variable disease penetrance within a family, where the index case carried the G allele, demonstrating reduced PTPN2 transcription that contributed to immunodeficiency. This finding was significant in highlighting the interplay between common variants and monogenic causes of PID, suggesting a mechanism for autoimmune development in the family.
title: Whole genome sequencing of a sporadic primary immunodeficiency cohort

finding: The marker rs12955474 reached Bonferroni-corrected significance in the replication analysis with a p-value of 5.59 × 10^-5, showing a shift of -0.17 standard deviations in HT. This SNP had been previously reported in a GWAS for the third principal component on HT over various frequencies.
title: Polygenic risk scores implicate genetic pathways involved in neurodevelopmental disorders in hearing thresholds and hearing asymmetry in children

finding: The SNP rs17782313 exhibited significant associations with all DEXA (dual-energy x-ray absorptiometry) traits through the SynSurr method, particularly showing the strongest association with total mass at a P-value of 1.8 × 10⁻²⁶. In contrast, the best P-value obtained through standard GWAS reached only 1.6 × 10⁻⁵. This SNP is well-known for its association with obesity.
title: Leveraging a machine learning derived surrogate phenotype to improve power for genome-wide association studies of partially missing phenotypes in population biobanks

finding: Identified as a lead variant at aQTL on chromosome 18, rs10775496 was highlighted as a genetic determinant of RELA regulatory activity in the cerebellar hemisphere tissue, with a p-value of 7.6×10⁻¹⁰. This SNP's context is critical as RELA is known to interact with SMAD4, the nearest gene.
title: Identifying Genetic Regulatory Variants that Affect Transcription Factor Activity

finding: This SNP is located in the 3'-UTR of the SMAD4 gene, and was noted as a plausible causal variant related to the aQTL on chromosome 18 revealed by the study, with a p-value of 7.8×10⁻¹⁰. Its relationship to RELA underscores its potential regulatory role.
title: Identifying Genetic Regulatory Variants that Affect Transcription Factor Activity

finding: The intronic SNP rs6566675, located in the NETO1 gene critical for spatial learning and memory, was found in a closed region in both the nucleus accumbens and dentate gyrus but opened in the Ammon's horn after METH stimulus.
title: Methamphetamine induced regional-specific transcriptomic and epigenetic changes in the rat brain

finding: The SNP rs12454712 was designated as a primary signal at the BCL2A locus with a TOA profile indicating shared effects between muscle (TOA=0.52) and adipose (TOA=0.48) tissues.
title: A multi-omic integrative scheme characterizes tissues of action at loci associated with type 2 diabetes

finding: The SNP rs12456492 in the RIT2 gene was linked to Parkinson's disease (PD) susceptibility through several studies. A meta-analysis by Lu et al. (2015) indicated a genetic association of the RIT2 rs12456492 polymorphism with increased risk of PD in Asian populations. Additionally, Liu et al. (2015) confirmed this association in a study conducted in Mainland China. A third meta-analysis by Zhang et al. (2015) further corroborated that the rs12456492 polymorphism is associated with a heightened risk of developing PD. These findings collectively suggest that rs12456492 is a significant genetic risk factor for PD.
title: Rit2 silencing in dopamine neurons drives a Parkinsonian phenotype

finding: The SNP rs17782313 was associated with greater long-term weight gain, increased risk of diabetes, and emotional eating in women. This finding highlighted the implications of MC4R signaling in relation to estrogen-dependency and metabolic health, particularly illustrating the differences observed between sexes in MC4R-related metabolic outcomes.
title: Estrogen Drives Melanocortin Neurons To Reduce Sedentary Behavior

finding: The SNP rs2217560 in the CBLN2 gene was associated with pulmonary arterial hypertension in systemic lupus erythematosus, suggesting its role in vascular diseases.
title: Identification of key genes and signaling pathway in the pathogenesis of Huntington’s disease via bioinformatics and next generation sequencing data analysis

finding: The hereditary point mutation rs76992529, which predisposed individuals of African descent to ATTR amyloidosis, exhibited a much lower impact on CRISPR/Cas9 editing with only 0.92% max variant effects across all associated Cas9-targeting sites. This indicated that the editing efficiency remained relatively comparable regardless of allele variation for this specific SNV, emphasizing the necessity for variant-aware gRNA selection to avoid ineffective gRNAs due to presence of variants in the target sequence.
title: CROTONdb: genome-wide variant effect prediction database for CRISPR/Cas9 editing outcomes

finding: The SNP rs12967143-G was identified as an intragenic enhancer within the TCF4 gene. It was predicted to be causal in SK-N-SH and H1 cells based on numerical scores generated through machine learning algorithms, while showing no significant causal prediction in HepG2 cells and PBMCs. This SNP met the significance criterion in comparison to randomly selected GWAS SNPs, indicating its relevance in the context of the ketamine pharmacogenomic network.
title: Ketamine’s pharmacogenomic network in human brain contains sub-networks associated with glutamate neurotransmission and with neuroplasticity

finding: This SNP was most associated with HDL in the Framingham Heart Study, though it differed from findings in the UK Biobank, highlighting variability in leading SNPs due to LD structure differences.
title: Multi-scale Inference of Genetic Trait Architecture using Biologically Annotated Neural Networks

finding: The SNP rs17782313 was identified as the second top obesity-associated GWAS SNP, located 187k bp from the MC4R gene. It was found to potentially disrupt binding of GATA binding protein 1 (GATA1), affecting enhancer activity and subsequently reducing MC4R expression by approximately 60% when knockout was achieved in differentiated neurons.
title: Integrative single-cell characterization of hypothalamus sex-differential and obesity-associated genes and regulatory elements

finding: The study reported that the risk allele C of the TCF4 rs9960767 polymorphism was linked to impairments in sensorimotor gating. This association was observed in both individuals with schizophrenia spectrum disorders and in healthy volunteers, indicating its relevance to schizophrenia related phenotypes.
title: Daughterless, the Drosophila orthologue of TCF4, is required for associative learning and maintenance of synaptic proteome

finding: In the atopic dermatitis GWAS, SNP rs35112771 was highlighted as an intronic SNP at the 18q21.33 locus. It showed notable colocalisation (83.5%) evidence with eQTLs specifically in sun-unexposed skin tissue for the gene SERPINB7. Notably, SERPINB7 is linked to Nagashima-Type Palmoplantar Keratosis, a phenotype commonly found in various eczematous conditions, suggesting that mutations impacting SERPINB7 could elucidate part of the heritability gap observed in atopic dermatitis.
title: MendelVar: gene prioritization at GWAS loci using phenotypic enrichment of Mendelian disease genes

finding: The variant rs6567160 also contributed to horizontal pleiotropy and had a positive causal effect with the smallest standard error of all variants discussed. It similarly suggested that the relationship between BMI and vigorous physical activity may not be causal.
title: Mendelian randomization suggests a bidirectional, causal relationship between physical inactivity and obesity

finding: The SNP rs12454712 was a primary signal at the BCL2A locus, showing shared effects in muscle (TOA=0.52) and adipose (TOA=0.48) tissues.
title: A multi-omic integrative scheme characterizes tissues of action at loci associated with type 2 diabetes

finding: The SNP rs12970134 was found to be positively associated with obese polycystic ovary syndrome (PCOS) patients in the Western region of Saudi Arabia. This association highlights the potential role of MC4R variants in the metabolic and reproductive disorders often observed in women with obesity, particularly in relation to PCOS.
title: POMC neurons control fertility through differential signaling of MC4R in Kisspeptin neurons in the female mouse

finding: The SNP rs17782313 was also positively associated with obese polycystic ovary syndrome (PCOS) patients in the Western region of Saudi Arabia. This suggests that the MC4R variants may influence fertility and metabolic health, aligning with the broader findings regarding the melanocortins' roles in energy balance and reproductive function.
title: POMC neurons control fertility through differential signaling of MC4R in Kisspeptin neurons in the female mouse

finding: The rs1052025 SNP near NFATC1 had a significant p-value of 3.6×10⁻⁴, marking it as a notable finding related to genetic differentiation, although it was not among the top hits like rs2549794.
title: Reply to Barton et al: signatures of natural selection during the Black Death

finding: The C allele of the rs9960767 polymorphism in TCF4 was reported to disrupt sensorimotor gating in individuals diagnosed with schizophrenia as well as in healthy volunteers. This finding highlighted the role of TCF4, which is associated with schizophrenia and related phenotypes, emphasizing its impact on cognitive processes linked to the disorder.
title: Daughterless, the Drosophila orthologue of TCF4, is required for associative learning and maintenance of synaptic proteome

finding: At the 18q21.33 locus, SNP rs35112771 demonstrated significant evidence of colocalization with SERPINB7 eQTLs specifically in sun-unexposed skin tissue, highlighting its potential role in skin conditions. Variants in SERPINB7 were associated with Nagashima-Type Palmoplantar Keratosis, a phenotype present in a range of eczematous conditions, suggesting that common mutations affecting SERPINB7 expression could contribute to the heritability observed in atopic dermatitis.
title: MendelVar: gene prioritization at GWAS loci using phenotypic enrichment of Mendelian disease genes

finding: The rs12456492 SNP, associated with the RIT2 gene, was identified as a risk allele for Parkinson's disease (PD) in a meta-analysis. This SNP was shown to be crucial for the mGluR5-stimulated retrieval of the dopamine transporter (DAT), indicating its role in dopaminergic signaling and function. The research underscored the importance of RIT2 in DAT trafficking, emphasizing that variations at this locus could potentially influence both dopamine clearance and motor functions in the context of PD.
title: Presynaptic Gq-coupled receptors drive biphasic dopamine transporter trafficking that modulates dopamine clearance and motor function
